Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2018 04:29PM Sassa wrote: Dear Jadedjo - My heart aches to read of your health issues and the cancer scare you are now undergoing. I can't offer any advice on what you may have to undergo if you do have cancer until you are diagnosed. However, your inability to lose weight , diabetes, and PCOS does sound very familiar. Starting in my forties, my weight just spiraled upward no matter how much I dieted or exercised. My blood glucose levels were creeping up and diabetes was a when, not an if. Cholesterol levels were very high and statins and diet did very little to lower it. I am willing to bet that, like me, you have high blood pressure, never really slept through the night and that you crave carbs like a drug addict craves their drug of choice. If you are diagnosed with breast cancer, I wouldn't be surprised if it is hormone negative. Now for the good news, about nine years ago I learned about metabolic syndrome (and you are a poster child for it) and about the benefit of carb controlled diets. My guru has turned out to be a registered dietitian named Diane Kress and her version of a carb controlled diet she calls the "Metabolism Miracle." She has worked with diabetics for years and developed her diet plan based upon the needs of her patients. Please google her and her diet plan. I can tell you that following her system I have lost over 100 lbs; my cholesterol levels are well within normal range without a statin; my blood pressure is controlled with one very low dose of drug; I sleep through the night and that I can easily pass up bread, pasta, and ice cream. Best of all, my mood (alright, I was downright cranky) has changed for the better. As I found out too late, having metabolic syndrome raised my risk of developing breast cancer and having it be hormone negative (on the other hand, there are no pesky side effects from hormone inhibitors as the drugs have no benefit for hormone negative breast cancer). Hoping for the best for you.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2013 01:43PM Sassa wrote: Two times with a PT is not enough. I had bilateral mastectomies, one was a modified radical mastectomy with SNB.  The modified mastectomy was 6 1/2 years ago; the simple one was six years ago. Your wife may have two issues contributing to her pain.  Depending on the size of the remaining breast, the body asymmetry may be pulling her chest, neck and shoulder muscles askew.  The six months between my two mastectomies was a painfest because of the asymmetry. The other issue is just the effects of the mastectomy. I have found that I need to exercise daily for flexibility and strength the muscles in the chest, upper back, neck and shoulders to stay pain free.  If I miss a few day, I start to tighten up. It took a good five years of daily exercise before I was relatively pain free.  I also found that a massage every few weeks also helped.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 03:01PM Sassa wrote: I am someone who had bilateral mastectomies for reasons other than breast cancer.  My right breast had the cancer, my left breast was "healthy." The problem was that I was over endowed and was suffering with the neck, back and shoulder pain that comes with that condition.  My breast cancer was found because I started doing the peliminary work-ups needed for breast reduction.   I was glad to get rid of "Massive Matilda," but that still left me with "Big Bertha" on the left side.  The body asymmetry made my muscles  go beserk and caused even more pain.  The plan was to document the pain (both my PCP and oncologists were willing participants in this) and go for a simple mastectomy. Luckily (?), my followup mammogram on the left side six months later came back as a BIRADS 5.  My oncologist told me she was 99.999% sure there was no cancer in the remaining breast and suggested I seize my opportunity and have a simple mastectomy with no other follow up testing. I did so and had the other beast (not a misspelling) removed in a simple mastectomy one week later. Pathology showed the breast to be totally healthy. What a joy to be flat chested!! I went without prostheses 99% of the time for two years and finally decided to go for reconstruction with tissue expanders and silicone implants.  I decided on reconstruction as I realized buying clothes when flat chested was as much a problem as when being over endowed. I had absolutely no problems with the whole reconstruction process and am now very happy with B cup sized breasts.  I don't have to wear a bra and have no discomfort from the implants. I consider my quality of life with the implants as superior in every way over life with the original equipment.  My one regret is that I had to have breast cancer to achieve my current status.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 04:24PM - edited Jan 30, 2008 05:18PM by Sassa I was a nervous wreck before my first chemo (AC).  I found out that receiving the chemo drugs was not a horrible experience and I frequently enjoyed the company of the other patients.  There were many a time we all were laughing at some joke or wisea*s comment. Several things you may wish to do: Start drinking water (or other fluid, no alcohol) 1 -2 days before your appointment.  You need to be well hydrated to pass the drugs through your system ASAP.  I was encouraged to bring bottles of water to drink during the drug infusion.  You will also need to stay well hydrated for several days after your appointment. Make sure you take your anti-nausea medication as directed.  You will probably need to take it for 3 -4 days after your chemo.  I found the anti nausea medications caused their own side effects (blurred vision, headache, and gave me the jitters). If your anti nausea medication doesn't seem to work (still feel nauseated or worse, throwing up), let your doctor know so the medication can be changed. Plan on eating bland food the day of and for several days afterwards.  Anything too spicy may make you feel ill. To save me from cooking, we stocked up on TV dinners.  My husband was happy eating his choice of frozen dinner and I could stick to the bland chicken and turkey ones.  Oatmeal was a good choice for breakfast. How many times do you need to go in for chemo?  I needed to go in 4 times, so after my first treatment I was 25% done.  After my second, I told myself I was 50% finished and on the downhill slope to the finish line.  Looking at the appointments in this way made me feel that I could do the chemo without a problem. Good luck - you can do it.

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 06:11AM Sassa wrote: Ordinarymammal, I was also overweight at the time of my BMX.  My goal was to lose weight before my diagnosis.  I found being flatchested gave me an extra push to work on the weight loss.  Without the big breasts on top, my fat stomach was too prominent.  I wanted to bring my silhouette into a better proportion.  It was so much more comfortable to exercise without the breasts flopping around and that helped with the weight loss. As far as not appearing in public without forms, I started noticing that 98% of the people in public didn't even notice my chest area, and; that was a big (wonderful) change for me because my huge breasts always attracted unwanted attention.  The few that did notice seemed to be women who would stare at me in horror.  If I noticed, I would smile and say, "Have you had a mammogram lately?"  For the young well-endowed young ladies who were fashionably dressed with their chests hanging out (what happen to modesty?), I would look at them and say, "In my day I could put your breast to shame.  Look really well, I am your possible future!." Robinlbe, Like you, I hated wearing bras before my mastectomies.  It was a huge disappointment to me to find out that BMX bras were even more ugly and uncomfortable than the iron maidens I used to wear before BC.  It didn't seem fair that I finally got rid of the beasts (not a misspelling!) and still had to wear ugly uncomfortable bras. What made me finally think about reconstruction was a cruise I took in October of 2008. I had decided I didn't want reconstruction.  I had some dresses that had lower necklines than I normally wore and needed some shape under them.  I invested in some protheses that were suppose allow me to stick them on my chest or attach them to my clothes (no bra straps to worry about). The prostheses just didn't work out that well and I realized that I was just too young at 58 to restrict myself to wearing Tee shirts or being totally frustrated by prostheses for the rest of my life.  After all, I had already spent my life since my teens dressing to fit my breasts, not for fashion.  That was when I seriously started to think about reconstruction. Best wishes for you all.  You will all eventually decide what you need or want.  There are pros and cons to both being flatchested or reconstructed.  Neither is all good or all bad However, your final right decision helps in the mental recovery from the BC journey..

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 08:39AM - edited Jan 5, 2013 08:40AM by Sassa mkkjd, As someone who used to handle waiver requests for clinical trials at the FDA, I am confused by what it is that you might want. If your mother is currently in the trial but in a different arm where the investigational product is not given, she will not get permission to use the investigational drug while the trial is continuing. If she is not in the trial, but seeks to have the drug outside the clinical trial, the trial sponsor (drug company) will have to agree to allow her to have the drug and submit what amounts to a specialized, individual IND (Investigational New Drug) application as part of their approved IND.  The doctor will also have to agree to become a clinical investigator, obtain local IRB (Institutional Review Board) approval and do all the paperwork and documentation required for the individualized study. Many sponsors will not allow use outside the trial as at this point, the purpose is to obtain data in a controlled study with certain criteria.  The data from the "compassionate" use will still have to be collected and submitted as data in their IND, but can not be included as part of the cohort data.  It is burdensome and not usefull for drug approval. There may also be problems with the cost of the drug and who will carry the cost.  If the patient is expected to pay, their insurance company will probably refued to cover the costs as the drug is not approved for marketing. If you are asking about receiving the drug after the clinical trial is done and the "NDA" (New Drug Application) is submitted but not yet approved for drug marketing, there can be several scenarios.  The sponsor can ask that after a preliminary review by FDA, permission be given to use the drug in additional study subjects.  If that approval is given, only a set number of additional subjects can receive the drug and again, there will be criteria for its use. A subject previously in the trial but who didn't receive the drug, may be eligible for the dug at this point.  Data will still be collected and submitted as part of the NDA. The company may be allowed to charge for the drug at this point.  However, because the drug has not been approved for marketing, insurance comapanies may refused to pay for the drug. Of course, a sponsor may not ask that additional subjects be added after submission of the NDA. As you can see, obtaining an investigational product outside a clinical trial is not simple and  may noy be something that either your mother's doctor, the local institution, or the sponsor be willing to allow.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2010 01:50PM Sassa wrote: Alloderm is a skin matrix.  It is made from cadaver skin (with permission of the deceased or the family, a lot of material is harvested from a body to be processed and reused - bones, skin and organs.  In most states, the eyeballs are taken without consent as states allow this by law.  The corneas are used in transplants.  That is why a body will have the eyelids sewn shut at a viewing - it is just cotton under them to give a contour to the lids.)  The skin is processed to remove any cellular characteristics of the donor (i.e, DNA, blood cell type) and sterilized.  When used, blood vessels and nerves will infiltrate the matrix and assumed the characteristics of the new host.  The product was originally developed for use in skin grafting  for burn patients. It is possible that your body is rejecting the new tissue (same problem as in any transplant) and causing the inflammation.  This is not an infection. An infection is caused by the introduction of microorganisms during surgery - a different kettle of fish. By the way, if anyone ever needs a new heart valve, it will be the processed heart valve of a pig that is used (pigs having the most similar tissue make up to humans).

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 01:12PM Sassa wrote: NanG, Here is the other perspective you asked for. Like you, I developed over sized breasts and I hated them.  Not for me the cute little tops, strapless gowns, anything with ruffles on the bustline.  My reality was clothes whose only criteria was that they fit and close over my bustline.  Bras were iron maidens that dug into my shoulders and the weigh of hauling the monsters around led to upper back, neck and shoulder pain and limited mobility in those areas. They hurt 28 out of 30 days a month and I couldn't stand to have them touched. I was blessed with a superior IQ, but was I ever known as the smart one?  No, I was described as the girl with the (hand gesture here with the hands held two feet away from the chest).  Just once, I wanted to have a conversation with either a male or female and not have the eyes stray to my chest and linger there. Finally, I couldn't deal with it all any more and decided to have a reduction.  First step, a mammogram earlier than my yearly one because a plastic surgeon wants to see one within the last month before doing a reduction.  Nothing obviously suspicious showed but I was told to come back in 6 months for a follow up.  Not going to happen so in I went for a biopsy.  The biopsy found a very small, aggressive tumor.  One week later I had the breast removed and cheered that it was gone. Now to get rid of the other beast (not a misspelling).  My PCP and oncologist both started documenting the pain I was in from the body asymmetry to convince the insurance company the the healthy breast should be removed.  Luckily, a mammogram 6 months later came back BIRADS 5.  In one week I had that one removed with no quibbles from the insurance company (pathology showed everything was benign in the breast). The day I came home from the second mastectomy, I  looked in the mirror at my flat chest and cheered:  THEY WERE GONE!!!!!!  I went gloriously flat chested for two years until I realized finding clothes for a flat chest was as difficult as finding them for a big one.  I checked into options for reconstruction and decided to do implants. Reconstruction was easy (TE's and exchange) and was done perfectly by my gifted plastic surgeon. I have beautiful, perky, B cup sized breasts that will never need a bra to hold them up.  They are pain free and I can finally wear all types of nice clothes. My foobs are superior in every way to the original equipment and they will never try to kill me.  If I had an offer of having my old breasts returned to me in a healthy state, I wouldn't accept the offer. My only regret is that I had to have breast cancer before the option of total removal was available to me. Why couldn't I just have this done in my twenties before the damage to my upper back, neck and shoulders occurred?

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2014 12:46PM - edited Nov 22, 2014 03:16PM by Sassa The symptoms you have definitely can be stressed related. When I was waiting for biopsy results, I couldn't sleep. I couldn't eat anything until about 1 PM or I would throw it back up. I couldn't concentrate on anything. You have a lot of company in your stress symptoms. By the way, the same thing happened to me. Eight years ago, I went in for a routine mammogram. It was classified BIRADS 3 (something there but probably benign). My primary care physician wasn't happy; she sent me right back in for a compression mammogram and an ultrasound. Both those came back with something there but probably benign. Again, my doctor wasn't happy and insisted I go in for a biopsy. I did and the rest is history. A small aggressive IDC was found. I am not saying this will be your outcome, but rather your doctor, just like mine was, is looking out for your best interests. Because my doctor wouldn't accept the BIRADs 3, my cancer was found very early and this was for the best. If no cancer had been found, I was spared the worry of waiting for the next mammogram and wondering if something was there. You will get an answer, and either way, the stress will either be gone or greatly reduced once you know what is in store for you.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 06:49PM Sassa wrote: The Birads classification causes us a lot of stress.  Like you, I was labeled a Birads 3 on both my left and right breast in 2006 and told to come back in 6 months. Because I wanted to have breast reduction, my PCP pushed for me to have compression mammograms and ultrasound.  Those ruled out the left breast as having a benign complex cyst and was label Birads 3. The right breast was still Birads 3 with no specific findings. My PCP then told me to have a biopsy done as a  plastic surgeon would not touch me unless it was clear what was going on in my breast. I had an excisional biopsy (lumpectomy by any other name) because no specific lumps could be detected in the area in question. That lumpectomy found my IDC and I went on to have a mastectomy of my right breast. Six months after the first mammogram, I went back in for the follow up on my left breast. That mammogram came back as BIRADs 5 because of calcifications. I went straight to having a simple mastectomy because I wanted to be evened out.  After slicing and dicing the whole breast, nothing was found that was not typical benign changes of an aging breast. I guess the point of my story is BIRADS just serms to be a crap shoot based on what the radiologist thinks might or might not be there.

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2008 05:01PM Sassa wrote: Yes, Decatur, the tests are done. Because of the biology of my BC, at the time of my surgery and around the time of my first chemo, I had a chest X-ray and CT/Pet Scan. My blood work included tumor markers and HCG levels.  I had a baseline bone scan done the same day as my mammogram as part of my yearly physical.  The bone scan showed a high bone density with no problem areas.  Because I was going to have AC and then Herceptin, I also had an echo cardiogram done before starting chemo. One year out from finishing chemo and finishing one year of herceptin, I am once again having a chest X-ray (no more mammos for me as I had both breasts removed), echo-cardiogram, and blood work.  There is also a CT/PET Scan in my future in a few months. Many of the tests are done to either provide a baseline or to see if there are any detectable mets. Be very happy that your doctor is so proactive.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2011 03:28PM Sassa wrote: Have you considered having guide wires placed and an excisional biopsy done? My mammogram 5 years ago showed a cluster of calcifications and was classified a Birads 3 with the recommendation of a six month follow up.  My PCP said no way and sent me to a surgeon for a biopsy.  Upon looking at the film, the surgeon said I had dense breasts which would make a needle biopsy difficult.  He suggested the guide wires and excisional biopsy (basically a lumpectomy).  I agreed. I am extremely glad I did.  In the cluster of microcalcifications was found a small, extremely aggressive IDC. The KI -67 was 70%. If I had waited six months, I would have probably been stage 4 instead of 1.  The tumor was so fast growing that I was glad it was gone with the biopsy. So while many breast cancers are slow growing, some are not and you don't know what you have until the pathology is done.

I can remember being in a total state of panic when I received my biopsy report.  I was sure I was Stage 4 with less than a year to live.  I had the dry heaves, couldn't eat and couldn't sleep.  My doctor gave me a Rx for Ambien CR so I could sleep (if I can sleep, I can handle almost anything). Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 06:50PM Sassa wrote: I am also another one whose cancer was found because of breast reduction.  I decided to have breast reduction done so my PCP sent me in several months early to have a mammogram (she said a plastic surgeon would want to know the breasts were clear).  When the results came back with a "there are microcalcifications, check in six months) my PCP immediately sent me to have a biopsy.  Because I wasn't into tissue saving, my surgeon asked for permission to do what he called a slit biopsy (have guide wires placed in the area of the microcals and he would take out as much tissue as he thought should be looked at). That is the way my small, highly aggressive breast tumor was found.  Having that early mammogram made the difference between Stage 1 and a much higher stage that would have been found at the time my mammogram would have been due. And I have the ultimate breast reductions - bilateral mastectomies with no reconstruction and I love being flat.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 10:05AM Sassa wrote: I recently talked to my PS on behalf of a friend who is a triple negative Stage III who had a mastectomy, chemo and rads.  She will be two years out from the end of rads in October. My PS said the better healed the skin is from the mastectomy and radiation, the better the results.  My friend  just started to think about reconstruction and feels at this point that she might want to get past the three year point (a significant point for recurrence risks for triple negs) before she might have something done. Best wishes to you.  Go talk to a PS about when might be the best time for reconstruction.  It might be alright to do now but better in the future. As someone currently doing reconstruction (2 years, 3 months out from chemo when expanders placed), I feel that a good reconstruction can't be rushed.  Because I was so far out from my mastectomies, I have had two years to gain back muscle flexibility in the chest, neck and shoulder areas through exercise and massage.  As a result, my PS said he was able to get excellent muscle coverage of the expanders (although he still did reinforce with alloderm) and can put in much more saline during fills without me feeling discomfort.

His daughter was someone I knew and had played with in summer camp just 1 month before his announcement.  I was mortified at my laughter and burst into tears. Lucky for me, the teacher understood. When my daughter was in second grade, her teacher came to me about the monster that my daughter was.  This dimwit had been talking about Martin Luther King Day and had shown pictures from the sixties to second graders of bloody civil rights protesters, black school children with German Shepherds lunging at them as they tried to go to school and a lynched black man. In the stillness of the classroom, my daughter started laughing and the teacher was furious. My daughter had nightmares for a week after that classroom lesson. I gave the teacher a brief discourse on how the body reacts to stress and suggested that she be more age appropriate in her visual aids. Maybe the young man was just shocked at seeing you hairless and didn't mean to laugh.  Of course, having once laughed, he was probably embarrassed and hightailed it out of the room.

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 05:08PM Sassa wrote: I thought I had full range of motion, also.  When I started doing the exercises, I realized that I didn't. I can't find my ACS booklet for post mastectomy exercises so I will tell you what exercises the physical therapist gave me for my shoulders and chest to "open" my chest up. Standing up, hold your arms down at your side with your lower arms extended in front of you at a 90 degree angle.  Press your shoulders backwards toward your shoulder blades.  Hold for a count of 5 seconds.  Repeat 15 times. Stand in a corner and place your forearms flat on both walls (left arm, left wall; right arm, right wall).  Lean in and hold for 20 seconds.  Repeat 3 times.  When you lean in, you should feel a pull across your chest.  If you don't, move back from the corner.  If I remember correctly, the ACS booklet has a similar exercise on a wall, not a corner.  The corner is more of a challenge. I find a hand towel the perfect length for the next exercise. Hold a towel diagonally across your back (like you are drying yourself).   One elbow should be  up in the air, the other arm is down and behind your back. With the arm with the elbow facing up, pull up on the towel which will pull your opposite shoulder and arm in towards your back and upwards.  Hold for 15 seconds.  Repeat 3 times. Switch arm positions and repeat. Extend your arms down and behind your back.  Hold a rod about 18 inches long in your hands (Palms up) behind your back.  Lift your arms upwards 15 times.  Holding a rod between your two hands causes less stress on the shoulders than clasping your hands behind your back  and lifting upwards. Standing up with your arms down at your sides, roll your shoulders back 20 times. I know there is an exercise in the ACS booklet that tells you to lie on your back with your arms at your side.  Hold onto and rod and lift up and over your head and touch the floor above your head.  I thought I had a full range of motion on this one until I tried to hold my arms over my head and touching the floor for a few seconds.  It has taken me several months, but I now can hold the extended position for two minutes.  I get too bored to try for a longer period.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2016 01:57PM Sassa wrote: I had a modified radical mastectomy with SNB on my right side on Nov 17, 2006. I had a simple mastectomy on my right side six months later. I eventually decided to do reconstruction with silicone implants in 2009. I know you don't want reconstruction, but it is part of my last 10 years. In any case, my biggest issues after the mastectomies were problems with my shoulder and neck. I feel the problems were ongoing from the problems I was already developing from being over endowed with breasts. However, I had physical therapy and faithfully did my exercises to strengthen and regain flexibility in my upper body. Two years after the mastectomies, I was pain free and in good shape. The reconstruction process was just a 6 month blip and was also pain and problem free. I have to say my QOL at this point is excellent and I am physically in better shape than before my mastectomies. I would like to comment about your math and science skills. I don't know if you are going to have chemotherapy. I had four AC (one AC infusion every three weeks), also 1 year of herceptin. The four AC temporarily destroyed my cognitive ability. From being able to solve quadratic equations in my head, I was reduced to needing a paper and pencil or a calculator to do the simplest addition and subtraction. I developed a language problem where I could think of a word, but wouldn't have the slightest idea of how to start spelling it. I also had problems trying to organize tasks. The language skills and ability to organize have come back. However, my math ability never really came back. I can now do very simple math in my head, but I really have to concentrate and use a calculator to solve complex equations.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 02:38PM Sassa wrote: Before chemo, are eyebrows and eyelashes do fall out, but as each hair is on their own timetable, they fall out separately.  I believe the life expectancy is about three months. When we have chemo, a lot of the lashes and brows are affected and fall out.  They grow back in and because their growth patterns are not randomized like before chemo, you will have the lashes and brows grow back in, only to have thinning occurring again about three months later (normal hair loss time period). The hairs seem to randomize themselves again, but it will take several years before the periodic thinning stops being noticeable.  I think it was bout three years for me after AC.  I did have a year of hereptin after the AC and the herceptin also affects the hair growth, so the three years may be longer than someone not on herceotin.

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2011 01:32PM - edited Aug 14, 2011 07:58PM by Sassa I have silicone implants.  With the exception of exercise restriction after the surgeries (TE and exchange), I have been allowed to go back to full exercise.  I was, however, restricted from doing push ups from the time of my TE placements to about 6 months after my exchange. My daily exercise consists of alternating bike riding with strength building and flexibility (same day for these last two).  My strength building consists of working out with resistance tubing and weights.   I work on my overall body flexibility but do about 20 minutes dedicated to chest, shoulder, upper back and neck muscles. I have had a pain free experience (of course there was some pain with the initial TE placement because of the muscle manipulation involved) with the fills, exchange and implants.  My PS attributes my experience to the excellent condition of my skin (no rads, two year delayed reconstruction) and my physical condition, especially of the pec muscles. I find that the toned and flexible pec muscles hold the implants in place with no discomfort.  NO bra!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2009 05:21PM Sassa wrote: If you read the survival statistics, the statistics are usually broken down into number (percent) still alive after five years, number alive without recurrence (NED), and number alive with recurrence. Also, keep in mind that the 5 year rates are based upon treatments that the patients received 5 years age.  A lot has changed in five years.  For example, it is less than 5 years that herceptin has been used to treat early stage HER2 positive BC.  Survival rates for HER2 Positive breast cancer does not reflect herceptin treatment that is the standard of care today.  It will probably be 2011 or 2012 before the statistics tables reflect the new survival rates for the HER2 positive BC patients.

Because I was extremely well endowed before my diagnosis, I later opted to have a simple mastectomy of my left breast to even me out (no reconstruction and no regrets). Depending on your age and breast size, you may wish to think about the simple mastectomy on the healthy side. I am currently undergoing physical therapy to help my back, neck and shoulders issues from carting all that weight around upfront  and the further aggravation from the 7 months when I so asymmetrical.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2008 12:21PM Sassa wrote: Shopaholic, Please listen carefully to your options.  With a grade 3 tumor, I can see why the doctor may push for a mastectomy.   At your age I would consider reconstruction if I opted for a mastectomy. I had bilateral mastectomies with no reconstruction.  However, I am close to 58 and feel that perky breasts would look ridiculous on me . There is a reconstruction forum on this board where women could answer questions about the process. Best wishes in your decision.

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 05:33PM Sassa wrote: I have a friend who was diagnosed about two years ago with IDC, Stage III, Triple negative.  She had her spleen removed over 20 years ago because of injury in an auto accident. She had a mastectomy, chemo and radiation. Nothing different was done because of her lack of a spleen.  She is now 1 1/4 year out from the end of chemo and doing well (her CT/PET scan last week was clear).

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 12:05PM Sassa wrote: I wore my regular bra during the day (not an underwire one) and used a sleep bra at night (bought it a Penney's). I also found showering to be painful without the bra.  So I showered with the bra on, pulling it down a side at a time to wash the breast area. My poor husband was called into service to hold my breast up while I dried off and put a new bra on. As I have posted before, I am sure this was not  one of his fantasies about my breasts when we first met.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 07:00PM Sassa wrote: I had dissolving sutures for my tissue expander surgery last June. The day after my outer stitches were removed, I saw a stitch sticking out of the incision.  I called the surgeon's office and they told me to just pull it out with tweezers. I did and, much to my surprise, a piece about 4 inches long pulled out.  Nothing fell down, fell off, or fell out so everything was fine. Two days ago, 4 months after surgery, another tiny piece worked its way out of the scar.  I just pulled it out with a tweezers (about the length of a short eyelash). I go in for my exchange surgery on Dec 10 and start the process all over again.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2008 12:26PM Sassa wrote: Kimbly, I finished chemo in February 07.  I had my other breast removed at the end of June 07 (no cancer involved).  I had a cruise scheduled in the middle of October. I have not had any reconstruction. I went on a two week trip to New Hampshire in the beginning of August.  I totally enjoyed my cruise in October. Please talk to your oncologist about traveling.  If your blood counts are normal, you should have no problems with traveling.
